content: Yep - but I'm watching Utah plat San Diego State - - Does carry some weight in my family, though, since Dad and his 3 younger brothers all went into WW II, fighting at places like North Africa, Sicily, Italy, Normandy, Saipan, Iwo Jima, and aboard the USS Saratoga when it was bombed and almost sunk. Somehow, they all managed to get home and raise families - - Wandering and Wondering
reply: Yep - but I'm watching Utah plat San Diego State - - Does carry some weight in my family, though, since Dad and his 3 younger brothers all went into WW II, fighting at places like North Africa, Sicily, Italy, Normandy, Saipan, Iwo Jima, and aboard the USS Saratoga when it was bombed and almost sunk. Somehow, they all managed to get home and raise families - - Wandering and Wondering
title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: My wife and my doctors will not allow me to watch again. The first 15 or so minutes are to intense. It is very good for some PTSD guys and not so good for others. God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: I bought the movie when it came out for sale. I served with some men, who I thought were far better men than I. I learned that I wasn't so darned bad myself. The part of it that haunts me though, is the "order" that the Captain gave as he was dying........EARN IT!! And the old man at the grave stone at the end of the movie, begging his wife to tell him he was a good man.....I think we all of us are, to one degree or another, haunted by that question. The fact that it is so important to us, I think, tells us that indeed we are, good men. T
reply: I bought the movie when it came out for sale. I served with some men, who I thought were far better men than I. I learned that I wasn't so darned bad myself. The part of it that haunts me though, is the "order" that the Captain gave as he was dying........EARN IT!! And the old man at the grave stone at the end of the movie, begging his wife to tell him he was a good man.....I think we all of us are, to one degree or another, haunted by that question. The fact that it is so important to us, I think, tells us that indeed we are, good men. T
title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: quote: Originally posted by Vicdude: Who here has seen it? It's on TNT right now. I donno how true to life it is but if it's only 25% true to life I don't understand how anyone watching it can have anything but the utmost respect for for our armed forces! Rodat first came up with the film's story in 1994 when he saw a monument dedicated to eight brothers who died during the American Civil War. Inspired by the story, Rodat decided to write a similar story set in World War II. The script was submitted to producer Mark Gordon, who then handed it to Hanks. It was finally given to Spielberg, who had previously demonstrated his interest in WWII themes with films such as Schindler's List, and decided to direct Saving Private Ryan after reading the film's script. The film's premise is very loosely based on the real-life case of the Niland brothers.
quote: Originally posted by Vicdude: Who here has seen it? It's on TNT right now. I donno how true to life it is but if it's only 25% true to life I don't understand how anyone watching it can have anything but the utmost respect for for our armed forces!
reply: Rodat first came up with the film's story in 1994 when he saw a monument dedicated to eight brothers who died during the American Civil War. Inspired by the story, Rodat decided to write a similar story set in World War II. The script was submitted to producer Mark Gordon, who then handed it to Hanks. It was finally given to Spielberg, who had previously demonstrated his interest in WWII themes with films such as Schindler's List, and decided to direct Saving Private Ryan after reading the film's script. The film's premise is very loosely based on the real-life case of the Niland brothers.
title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: Kinda feel like the Ryan kid. All my buddies went. Some didn't come back. I end up in Germany doing nothing. Went and saw it when it first came out with my wife. She was in Germany with me when I learned that some of my friends had been killed in Nam. That last scene in the movie in the Grave Yard tore us both up pretty bad - - Wandering and Wondering
reply: Kinda feel like the Ryan kid. All my buddies went. Some didn't come back. I end up in Germany doing nothing. Went and saw it when it first came out with my wife. She was in Germany with me when I learned that some of my friends had been killed in Nam. That last scene in the movie in the Grave Yard tore us both up pretty bad - - Wandering and Wondering
title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: War is up close and personal. Adrenalin gives us the strength and bravery required for the fight for life and reaction is the training we endured over and over. It’s only after the battlefields are quiet and time catches up with the present that we have time to think about those battles. The movie does well at showing that aspect of war.
reply: War is up close and personal. Adrenalin gives us the strength and bravery required for the fight for life and reaction is the training we endured over and over. It’s only after the battlefields are quiet and time catches up with the present that we have time to think about those battles. The movie does well at showing that aspect of war.
title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: At the beginning of the movie are those moments when shock makes things "go away" a little bit. The sound effect to me was particularly powerful as it has happened to me more than once. The roaring in your ears is real, and one of the things I remember the most, about time stretching and then snapping back so that you return to "the moment". The swift boat scene in Apocolypse Now where they were tooling up the river and suddenly came under fire, was especially spooky to me ( no I didn't have THAT moment but one like it) the "flaming onions" started coming in, even before you hear the noise of their being fired, and I threw myself down on the floor....in the theater!! Most embarrassing!!! No, I didn't go to Viet Nam, I volunteered twice but didn't go.
reply: At the beginning of the movie are those moments when shock makes things "go away" a little bit. The sound effect to me was particularly powerful as it has happened to me more than once. The roaring in your ears is real, and one of the things I remember the most, about time stretching and then snapping back so that you return to "the moment". The swift boat scene in Apocolypse Now where they were tooling up the river and suddenly came under fire, was especially spooky to me ( no I didn't have THAT moment but one like it) the "flaming onions" started coming in, even before you hear the noise of their being fired, and I threw myself down on the floor....in the theater!! Most embarrassing!!! No, I didn't go to Viet Nam, I volunteered twice but didn't go.
title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: “Yeh, me too. I was even issued M-3 .45 Cal. Grease Gun for a while, before they gave M-16s to Tankers - -“ Just before I left for DS/DS I too was issued an M-3…Man! What a beast that was at the firing range. It took a couple of clips to get used to it, but I finally got a “good spray pattern down”. I was going with 4-32AR, and they were deactivating the whole division… and so started signing over equipment to other units…I got 40 rds to take with me and All I thought about was how easily this thing rusted! I was cleaning 2 times a day…I even got a 4856 because the PSG thought I had not cleaned it… Thank goodness the C of C got the M-16s back in time for the plane ride over. Though I wouldn’t mind having it now in my safe…! I can’t watch that movie anymore, or we were Soldiers once. WWII and Vietnam were not of my era, but still have many family and friends who were there. Break glass…in case of Emergency! Or, just wait till I get to the bottom of the bottle!
reply: “Yeh, me too. I was even issued M-3 .45 Cal. Grease Gun for a while, before they gave M-16s to Tankers - -“ Just before I left for DS/DS I too was issued an M-3…Man! What a beast that was at the firing range. It took a couple of clips to get used to it, but I finally got a “good spray pattern down”. I was going with 4-32AR, and they were deactivating the whole division… and so started signing over equipment to other units…I got 40 rds to take with me and All I thought about was how easily this thing rusted! I was cleaning 2 times a day…I even got a 4856 because the PSG thought I had not cleaned it… Thank goodness the C of C got the M-16s back in time for the plane ride over. Though I wouldn’t mind having it now in my safe…! I can’t watch that movie anymore, or we were Soldiers once. WWII and Vietnam were not of my era, but still have many family and friends who were there. Break glass…in case of Emergency! Or, just wait till I get to the bottom of the bottle!
title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: Yep - but I'm watching Utah plat San Diego State - - Does carry some weight in my family, though, since Dad and his 3 younger brothers all went into WW II, fighting at places like North Africa, Sicily, Italy, Normandy, Saipan, Iwo Jima, and aboard the USS Saratoga when it was bombed and almost sunk. Somehow, they all managed to get home and raise families - - Wandering and Wondering

content: My wife and my doctors will not allow me to watch again. The first 15 or so minutes are to intense. It is very good for some PTSD guys and not so good for others. God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: I bought the movie when it came out for sale. I served with some men, who I thought were far better men than I. I learned that I wasn't so darned bad myself. The part of it that haunts me though, is the "order" that the Captain gave as he was dying........EARN IT!! And the old man at the grave stone at the end of the movie, begging his wife to tell him he was a good man.....I think we all of us are, to one degree or another, haunted by that question. The fact that it is so important to us, I think, tells us that indeed we are, good men. T
reply: I bought the movie when it came out for sale. I served with some men, who I thought were far better men than I. I learned that I wasn't so darned bad myself. content: quote: Originally posted by Vicdude: Who here has seen it? It's on TNT right now. I donno how true to life it is but if it's only 25% true to life I don't understand how anyone watching it can have anything but the utmost respect for for our armed forces! Rodat first came up with the film's story in 1994 when he saw a monument dedicated to eight brothers who died during the American Civil War. Inspired by the story, Rodat decided to write a similar story set in World War II. The script was submitted to producer Mark Gordon, who then handed it to Hanks. It was finally given to Spielberg, who had previously demonstrated his interest in WWII themes with films such as Schindler's List, and decided to direct Saving Private Ryan after reading the film's script. The film's premise is very loosely based on the real-life case of the Niland brothers.
quote: Originally posted by Vicdude: Who here has seen it? It's on TNT right now. I donno how true to life it is but if it's only 25% true to life I don't understand how anyone watching it can have anything but the utmost respect for for our armed forces!
reply: Rodat first came up with the film's story in 1994 when he saw a monument dedicated to eight brothers who died during the American Civil War. Inspired by the story, Rodat decided to write a similar story set in World War II. The script was submitted to producer Mark Gordon, who then handed it to Hanks. It was finally given to Spielberg, who had previously demonstrated his interest in WWII themes with films such as Schindler's List, and decided to direct Saving Private Ryan after reading the film's script. The film's premise is very loosely based on the real-life case of the Niland brothers.
title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: Kinda feel like the Ryan kid. All my buddies went. Some didn't come back. I end up in Germany doing nothing. Went and saw it when it first came out with my wife. She was in Germany with me when I learned that some of my friends had been killed in Nam. That last scene in the movie in the Grave Yard tore us both up pretty bad - - Wandering and Wondering
reply: Kinda feel like the Ryan kid. All my buddies went. Some didn't come back. I end up in Germany doing nothing. Went and saw it when it first came out with my wife. She was in Germany with me when I learned that some of my friends had been killed in Nam. That last scene in the movie in the Grave Yard tore us both up pretty bad - - Wandering and Wondering
title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: War is up close and personal. Adrenalin gives us the strength and bravery required for the fight for life and reaction is the training we endured over and over. It’s only after the battlefields are quiet and time catches up with the present that we have time to think about those battles. The movie does well at showing that aspect of war.
reply: War is up close and personal. Adrenalin gives us the strength and bravery required for the fight for life and reaction is the training we endured over and over. It’s only after the battlefields are quiet and time catches up with the present that we have time to think about those battles. The movie does well at showing that aspect of war.
title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: At the beginning of the movie are those moments when shock makes things "go away" a little bit. The sound effect to me was particularly powerful as it has happened to me more than once. The roaring in your ears is real, and one of the things I remember the most, about time stretching and then snapping back so that you return to "the moment". The swift boat scene in Apocolypse Now where they were tooling up the river and suddenly came under fire, was especially spooky to me ( no I didn't have THAT moment but one like it) the "flaming onions" started coming in, even before you hear the noise of their being fired, and I threw myself down on the floor....in the theater!! Most embarrassing!!! No, I didn't go to Viet Nam, I volunteered twice but didn't go.
reply: At the beginning of the movie are those moments when shock makes things "go away" a little bit. The sound effect to me was particularly powerful as it has happened to me more than once. The roaring in your ears is real, and one of the things I remember the most, about time stretching and then snapping back so that you return to "the moment". The swift boat scene in Apocolypse Now where they were tooling up the river and suddenly came under fire, was especially spooky to me ( no I didn't have THAT moment but one like it) the "flaming onions" started coming in, even before you hear the noise of their being fired, and I threw myself down on the floor....in the theater!! Most embarrassing!!! No, I didn't go to Viet Nam, I volunteered twice but didn't go.
title: "Saving Pvt. Ryan"

content: “Yeh, me too. I was even issued M-3 .45 Cal. Grease Gun for a while, before they gave M-16s to Tankers - -“ Just before I left for DS/DS I too was issued an M-3…Man! What a beast that was at the firing range. It took a couple of clips to get used to it, but I finally got a “good spray pattern down”. I was going with 4-32AR, and they were deactivating the whole division… and so started signing over equipment to other units…I got 40 rds to take with me and All I thought about was how easily this thing rusted! I was cleaning 2 times a day…I even got a 4856 because the PSG thought I had not cleaned it… Thank goodness the C of C got the M-16s back in time for the plane ride over. Though I wouldn’t mind having it now in my safe…! I can’t watch that movie anymore, or we were Soldiers once. WWII and Vietnam were not of my era, but still have many family and friends who were there. Break glass…in case of Emergency! Or, just wait till I get to the bottom of the bottle!
reply: “Yeh, me too. I was even issued M-3 .45 Cal. Grease Gun for a while, before they gave M-16s to Tankers - -“ Just before I left for DS/DS I too was issued an M-3…Man! I was cleaning 2 times a day…I even got a 4856 because the PSG thought I had not cleaned it… Thank goodness the C of C got the M-16s back in time for the plane ride over. Though I wouldn’t mind having it now in my safe…! I can’t watch that movie anymore, or we were Soldiers once. WWII and Vietnam were not of my era, but still have many family and friends who were there. Break glass…in case of Emergency! Or, just wait till I get to the bottom of the bottle!
